return simpleCsvParser(usCasesData);
return simpleCsvParser(usDeathsData);
return apogeeutil.textRequest(usDeathsUrl);
return apogeeutil.textRequest(worldDeathsUrl);
return apogeeutil.textRequest(worldRecoveredUrl);
return simpleCsvParser(worldDownloadedData);
return simpleCsvParser(worldDeathsData);
return simpleCsvParser(worldRecoveredData);

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;

if(regionPath.length == 0) return normalizedData.mergedWorldData;

return _lookupEntry(normalizedData.mergedWorldData,regionPath,0);
return regionPath.join(", ");
return selectedEntry.data;

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;
return normalizedData.mergedWorldData.regions.US;
return processedStateData.map( (inEntry,index,array) => _createDataSet(inEntry,index,array.length));
return inData.map( value => value*multiplier);

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;
return apogeeutil.jsonRequest(usStatePopulationUrl + "&key=" + apiKey);
return row.slice(columnDefs.FIRST_DATA_ROW).map(stringValue => parseInt(stringValue));

content.text: Data Download
This data is downloaded from a Github site managed by Johns Hopkins:
https://github.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19
World Data
The url below is raw world cases data in csv format.
The url below is raw world deaths data in csv format.
The url below is raw world recovered data in csv format.
Here is the raw downloaded cases data:
Here is the raw downloaded deathsdata:
Here is the raw downloaded recovered data:
Here is the world cases data processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Here is the world deaths data processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Here is the world recovered data processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Below is the column numbering for the data, with the first column being column 0. This applies to all three world tables.
US Data
The url below is raw cases data in csv format for the US.
The url below is raw cases data in csv format for the US.
Here is the raw cases data.
Here is the raw deaths data.
Here is the US cases processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Here is the US deaths processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Below are some column numbers from the above grid, with the first column being column 0. This only applies to the cases data. The deaths data has an additional column, population.
Below are some column numbers from the deaths grid data, with the first column being 0. Note that this table contains one additional column not in the cases data.
Simple CSV Parser

This is a simple CSV parser. It will work if there are ZERO or ONE of the internal fields that are quote delimited. It will throw an error if this condition is not met. This works with our current input data.
Workspace Notes
This page contains various notes regarding the workspace, such as items I want to go back and improve.
To Do
For the selector on the plots page, I need to add an "all" entry for each child list (country, state, county) if there is data for "all".
To Improve
The parsing of the text data is really a cludge. I will parse the data if there are 0 or 1 fields that are delimited with quotes (because of an included comma). I should generalize this.
Right now I have a lot of code in a number of cells.
Other Issues
The grids will often get corrupted  (I think if you scroll from the top and leave the page). This is a bug in my grid view.
Normalized Data
This page contains normalized data created from the downloaded data. We will combine the US and World data into one hierarchical structure.
Step 1. Modified Row Data
This cell contains an array of elements, each of which contains the data from a row of the world or US data.
This function gets the times series data from an input grid row. It can also be used on the header row to get the date entries.
Step 2. Combine into Hierarchical Data

Here we create the hierarchical data. This has a single world entry, with child entries for countries, which in turn have child entries for states (provinces, etc) , which in turn have child entries for counties (or immediate other sub-state  admin region).
Step 3. Fill in Missing Data

Here we sum child entries to populate missing data for parent entries - meaning counts (based on the sum of all child counts) and lat lon (based on the simple, equally weighted average of the child lat lons).
Plot Data
This table should hold the name of the county, including the full state name and country abbreviation.
Here are some graphing options:
Chart
This is a chart of COVID-19 cases for the selected region.
The following tables are input to the chart.
The data series:
The chart options:
Selected Data
Here we process the form selections to create the chart data.
This is the selected data entry:
This is the selected time series for total cases:
This is the selected time series for new cases:
Multiplot Test
We will plot the number of cases per the following population for the given states
This form selects the data to plot for the selected states.
This form selects the state to plot.
Chart Data
Data Processing
This is the data entry for the US.
Here we merge the COVID data with the downloaded population, where available, and reformat into a state map.
This is a list of the states and other US regions.
This is an array of entries for the selected states.
Here is the processed state data, showing the number of new cases per given population number as given by the field
casesPer
Time Series Processing Functions
All these functions take a time series input and return a time series of the same length.
This function takes a difference of entries. To end up with the same length of array, this creates a virtual entry of index -1 with value 0.
This function divides each entry by the input number
Population Data
This is a URL to download state population from the US Census. Unfortunately I haven't figured out how to get data for the US territories included in the COVID data.
Here is the API key.
Here is the data.
Here is the data reformatted into a lookup table.
World Population Table
This is a 2020 population of countries taken from the web  page
https://worldpopulationreview.com/
US Processed Data
This is data processed from the US datasets.
Here we combine the cases and deaths data.
Here we clean up the data:
delete entries with incomplete data (There are some territories at the end)
add the counts from counties and put these in the state entries.
Here we do a few additional checks. The array result should be a list of errors.
Utilities
